Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2017 Workshop on the Economics of Information Security (WEIS)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: This proposal supports 12 students for their travel to attend the 16th Workshop on the Economics of Information Security (WEIS) held at the University of California San Diego, on June 26-27, 2017. WEIS is an annual event that serves as a leading forum for interdisciplinary scholarship on information security, combining expertise from the fields of computer science and electrical engineering, economics, social science, business, law, and policy. Student participation in WEIS is a critical part of the educational experiences of students with interdisciplinary interests related to security and privacy. WEIS provides them an opportunity to interact with senior researchers and to be exposed to leading work in the field. As such, it fits closely with the goals of NSF's Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace (SaTC) program, which include socio-economic approaches to information security.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The field of the economics of privacy and security has grown substantially since the first instance of the Workshop on the Economics of Information Security (WEIS). However, the workshop has remained the leading forum for interdisciplinary scholarship on information security, combining expertise from the fields of computer science and electrical engineering, economics, social science, business, law, and policy. This grant supported the 16th Workshop on the Economics of Information Security, which was held in June 2017 in La Jolla, California, hosted by the University of California San Diego.

This year, WEIS received 73 submissions of which 24 were accepted. This award helped support 13 graduate students attend the workshop. Awards were made to three female and ten male students, with five of them having their research appear on the program at WEIS. The awardees represented the following academic institutions: New York University, Pennsylvania State University, Indiana University, University of California Davis, University of Tulsa, University of Illinois at Chicago, Princeton University, University of Arizona, Illinois Institute of Technology, and Tufts University. Their attendance furthered their education by exposing them to cutting edge interdisciplinary research surrounding information security, as well as enabled them to meet and interact with senior researchers in the field, gather ideas for potential new research directions and thesis topics, and disseminate their own research.
